awd_titl_txt: IDBR: TYPE A/Surface-sensitive coherent Raman microscopy (SCRM): label-free chemical imaging of dynamics at the cell surface
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to the University of California, Irvine (UCI), to develop a new type of microscope that can be used to study the properties of cell membranes. The SCRM instrument provides a unique solution for cell membrane studies where the use of fluorescent labels is questionable, thus enabling new discoveries in cell biology and membrane biophysics not previously possible with current technologies. The development and application of the SCRM technology forms a thorough training opportunity for two graduate students and one undergraduate student in the areas of engineering, optical physics and biology. An important component of this program is to bring the new SCRM technology into the classroom, which is achieved by using the prototype instrument in a graduate level course on Molecular Biophysics. The new microscope will also be actively used in the Laboratory Experiments & Activities in the Physical Sciences (LEAPS) program, which brings underrepresented students from the Santa Ana School District to the UCI campus. 

The special feature of this microscope is its capability to interrogate membranes of live cells with high contrast, but without the use of fluorescent labels. This new mode of inquisition, called surface-sensitive coherent Raman microscopy (SCRM), is achieved through merging the imaging properties of two existing techniques: coherent Raman scattering (CRS) microscopy and total internal reflection illumination. Compared to conventional CRS microscopy, SCRM offers a ten times higher axial resolution at imaging speeds of more than 10 frames per second.

por.por_cntn:
Detecting a small object in a large volume is generally challenging. In optical imaging, for instance, the signal from small objects may get buried in the overall background signal coming from the (large) sampling volume. Naturally, the sensitivity can be increased dramatically if the sampling volume is decreased. One way to achieve this is by using a very special illumination trick, which couples light to the surface of a glass substrate window, the so-called total internal reflection illumination scheme. In this fashion, the sampling volume is confined to the surface: only objects within ~100 nm from the glass are detected. 

 

This illumination scheme has been used with great success to visualize membranes of cells. When membranes are close to the surface, they produce strong signals, whereas the rest of the cell, which is outside the sampling volume, barely contributes to the image. However, so far, researchers have only been able to highlight membranes this way by attaching fluorescent dyes to the membrane. In some cases, fluorescent dyes disturb the cell or affect the experiment negatively. Hence, it would be very desirable to use the surface illumination scheme without the use of such fluorescent labels.

 

In this project, we have been able to detect biological membranes with the surface illumination method. Instead of using labels, we used the intrinsic vibrational spectroscopic properties of the membrane molecules. This type of molecular spectroscopy is called Raman scattering. Since the Raman signal is much weaker than fluorescent signals, a special form of amplification was needed. To accomplish this, we coated the glass substrate with a thin layer of gold, which enabled the excitation of extra strong surface fields, the so-called surface plasmon fields. Under these conditions, and by using short laser pulses, we were able to achieve amplifications of more than a million times, giving rise to detectable signals from the biological membranes that were placed on the gold surface. The resulting microscope can be thought of as a label-free chemical imaging scope with a built-in signal amplification scheme.

 

Using this microscope, we have recorded images of membrane vesicles and cells adhered to the substrate, without the use of labels. We also provided a theoretical model of the underlying physical mechanism that makes this form of imaging possible. In addition, we discovered that the gold-coated glass surface also functions as a luminescent sensor: every time a small sub-micrometer particle comes close to the gold film, the gold becomes luminescent. Since it is very easy to detect the luminescent emission, this property can be used to detect the proximity of sub-micrometer particles near the gold surface. This implies that, beside the ability to detect lipid membranes and vesicles, the same microscope can be used to visualize any sub-micrometer structure that is proximal to the surface. These two capabilities have interesting applications in biological imaging and in particle sensing.
